original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares up at close on foreign interest
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares closed higher on Tuesday, with more foreign participation seeing in the market due to positive macro economic sentiments, an analyst said.

The main All Share Price Index was up 0.79 percent or 74.04 points at 9,442.95, this is the highest the market has been since March 22, while the most liquid index S&P SL20 was up 0.70 percent or 18.73 points at 2,713.65.

The market generated a sizable net foreign inflow of 336 million rupees, this is the highest net foreign inflows have been since February 14, bringing the total outflow for the year to 427 million rupees.
Most of the net foreign inflows came in from the biggest and most liquid index holder, John Keells Holdings.
Sri Lanka domestic debt restructuring (DDR) will not affect the stability of any public or private bank or the member balance of any provident funds, President Ranil Wickremesinghe has said.
Sri Lanka will announce its DDR this week amid market speculations over instability in financial and banking sectors.

“Furthermore, the President stated that the restructuring of domestic debt will not pose any threat to the stability of the country’s banking system, whether it be public or private banks. He specifically mentioned that the deposits of more than 50 million bank depositors will remain unaffected, and there will be no changes to the current interest rates paid on bank deposits,” President Wickremesinghe said.
“The domestic debt optimization has been discussed with the finance ministry and central bank and has come to the final stage,” Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe told reporters.
“We can certify that bank and non-bank deposits or interest will not be reduced or harmed in any way,” Weerasinghe said.
Party leaders are expected to meet this week to decide on weekend sessions on July 01 and 02 to debate the debt re-structuring strategy.

The market was buoyed by assurances of debt restructuring and optimization, with the central bank cutting the key policy rates by 250 basis points to stimulate faltering economic growth as inflation was decelerating faster than projected.

Sri Lanka’s broader National Consumer Price Index (NCPI) grew by 22.1 percent in the 12 months to May, down from 33.2 percent a month ago, according to data from the Department of Census and Statistics.
An International Monetary Fund mission stated that Sri Lanka needs more revenues and debt restructuring by September to achieve sustainable debt levels after their visit to the island.
A number of middle-income countries which are under debt stress should be helped to overcome the situation before they default, Sri Lanka President Ranil Wickremesinghe has said.
…[W]e should deal with the issues of middle-income countries because most are under stress,” President Wickremesinghe told a global forum.
“It’s better to deal with them under stress than when they are bankrupt. So that process has to evolve.”
Lowered policy rates and inflation encouraged investors to invest in banking, capital and food, beverages and tobacco, alleviating fears of domestic debt optimization and restructuring.
Sri Lanka’s State Minister of Finance Shehan Semasinghe stated that once a final decision has been made on domestic debt optimization, the government will inform both parliament and the public.

“This is an extremely sensitive matter that significantly influences the market situation. It is vital that we refrain from making statements that create doubts regarding this optimization, as it helps maintain stability in our financial market,” said the president’s media division in an official translation of the state minister’s remarks.
Top gainers during trade were Browns Investment, Melstacorp and Sampath Bank.

The market generated revenue of 2.2 billion rupees, while the average turnover was 1.4 billion rupees, the highest recorded revenue since June 15. The capital goods sector contributed 706 million rupees, while the banking sector contributed 536 million rupees and 273 million rupees was contributed by the diversified financials sector. (Colombo, June 28, 2023)
